summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) Program Statement (P5264.08) detailing the national policy and procedures for inmate telephone privileges within BOP institutions and contract facilities. It outlines regulations for telephone list preparation, call monitoring, limitations, and security procedures, with no specific mention of Jeffrey Epstein or any individuals involved in his case. This document is a Bureau of Prisons policy (P5264.08) detailing procedures for inmate telephone use, monitoring, restrictions, and authorization of non-standard telephone systems. It outlines rules for attorney calls, monitored calls during crises, inmate financial responsibility, and circumstances under which the Warden can impose telephone restrictions.

keyFacts: This document is a general BOP policy statement on inmate telephone regulations, not specific to any individual case.
The policy establishes procedures for inmate telephone list preparation, monitoring, call blocking, and limitations (e.g., 300 minutes per month).
It specifies that inmate calls to attorneys may be unmonitored under certain circumstances, but all other calls are subject to monitoring for institutional security.
The document rescinds a prior version (P5264.07) and incorporates several policy changes, including deletion of references to the Washington v. Reno settlement.
There is no mention of Jeffrey Epstein, his associates, victims, or any events related to his case within this text.
The document establishes Bureau of Prisons policy P5264.08, effective January 24, 2008, governing all aspects of inmate telephone use.
It details strict procedures for authorizing and monitoring non-standard inmate telephones (Non-ITS), requiring Warden and Regional Director approval and mandatory recording of calls.
The policy authorizes Wardens to impose telephone restrictions on inmates based on a Public Safety Factor (PSF) for 'Serious Telephone Abuse' or pending investigations into telephone abuse.
Inmates are financially responsible for telephone use, but provisions exist for collect calls for indigent inmates or during family emergencies at the Warden's discretion.
All inmate telephone calls, except unmonitored attorney calls, are subject to monitoring and recording, with inmates required to acknowledge this monitoring.
